   - Started on treatment for PCP- [**Name10 (NameIs) 1369**] and prednisone

   for PCP
   [**11-3**] Urine culture pending, NGTD
   Radiology Studies:
   [**11-3**] High resolution chest CT:
   1. Recent changes over four days documented by conventional chest
   radiographs
   indicate that at least some of the reticular and ground-glass
   abnormalities in
   the lungs, which have worsened since [**10-29**] are pulmonary edema.
   The
   progression of the same abnormalities between [**10-9**] and [**10-29**] could
   be due to some component of interstitial lung disease, which was
   clearly
   present on the earliest examination.
   2. Persistent pulmonary arterial hypertension and global cardiomegaly.
   Severe
   coronary atherosclerotic calcification. Aortic valvular calcification
   of
   uncertain significance.
   3. Large thyroid cysts or nodules. Ultrasound examination recommended
   if not
   already obtained.
   For subsequent evaluation of the progression of pulmonary edema or
   interstitial lung disease, conventional radiograph should be employed
   as a
   first step.
   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 79 yo M with PMH DM2, interstitial lung disease,
   diastolic CHF, CAD s/p NSTEMI with recent diagnosis of unresectable
   cholangiocarcinoma s/p CBD excision, cholecystectomy, lymph node bx,
   PTC placement and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, with no further
   surgical management, transferred to MICU for hypoxia, feeling well but
   remaining hypoxic.
   .
   # Hypoxia
 Patient continued to be on non-rebreather for the better
   part of yesterday. This morning he was transitioned to a high-flow mask
   and is impoved on that. Read of high resolution chest CT yesterday was
   suspicious for pulmonary edema in setting of underlying interstitial
   lung disease, however overall picture is more consistent with an
   atypical infection or PCP in setting of his interstitial lung disease.
   Will not purse further diuresis given he overall appears euvolemic and
   had hypotension after diuresis yesterday.  We are continuing treatment
   for PCP in the setting of his elevated LDH and long-term steroid use
   and CT that could be consistent with this.  Less likely is lymphangitic
   spread of carcinoma.- Patient just completed 7 days of levofloxacin
   (day 1 = [**2138-10-27**])
   - Ordered induced sputum culture for PCP stain as well, given that the
   only negative PCP stain is from a sample that was contaminated.
   Currently patient appears too tenuous to bronch at present.
   - Initiate steroid treatment for PCP yesterday, which will also treat
   his intersitial lung disease, if this is playing role. Plan will be for
   prednisone 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] for 5 days (day 1 = [**11-3**]), 40 mg daily for 5 days,
   then 20 mg for 11 days. Initiated [**Month/Year (2) **] IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]) for PCP
   treatment as well.
   - Initiated vancomycin and zosyn today for hospital acquired PNA (day 1
   = [**11-4**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed
   - Continue attempt to wean O2, to keep sat >92%
   - Will hold off PFTs as not likely to be helpful in setting of acute
   decompensation.
   - ICU fellow [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 955**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 90**] discussed case with patient
s outpatient
   pulmonologist, Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5568**]. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5568**] reported that the patient had
   presented several years ago and had diffuse changes on CT (ground
   glass, fibrosis). The patient was initially treated with high dose
   steroids, then quickly tapered down to maintance dose (2.5-10 mg per
   reports).  A bronchosocpy was never completed per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5568**]
s report.
   This would likely be helpful for additional work up, but patient
   remains too tenuous to bronch at present.
   .
   # Fever, leukocytosis: Resolved from yesterday, when there had been
   concern for infection in setting of low grade temp and leukocytosis.
   Continuing to monitor for infection (possible sources including urinary
   given foley, lung given hypoxia, and GI given percutaneous drain).
   - Will follow up culture data, antibiotics as noted above should also
   cover gram negative pathogens from GU/GI tract.
   .
   # Hypotension
 Yesterday had transient hypotension (80
s), which was
   asymptomatic. This episode was likely secondary to his diruesis after
   the lasix he received. His borderline low BP remains likely
   multifactorial with differential diagnosis including intravascularly
   depleted vs adrenal insufficiency in setting of long term steroid use
   vs diabetic autonomic dysfunction. Yesterday concern was for possibly
   brewing sepsis, but resolved today. Will consider tolerating if
   mentating, making urine, asymptomatic and MAP >55-60.
   - Goal SBP >100
   - AM cortisol was 24.5 on [**11-2**], on steroids [**Hospital1 **] for above reasons.
   - Holding lisinopril given recent creatinine bump.
   - If possible, once more stable, will consider addition of low dose
   metoprolol given recent NSTEMI if tolerated by bp
   .
   # Cholangio CA, biliary stricture - Curative surgery not possible,
   reconstruction with roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy performed in [**Month (only) 705**]
   [**2138**].
   - Follow-up as outpatient with oncology
will try to reach patient
   primary oncologist today to further discuss his prognosis to help
   further discuss goals of care and how aggressively to further work up
   and treat his pulmonary process.
   - Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 511**]
s team will see patient today to help guide
   recommendations for drain, appreciate assistance. Tube is in place
   mainly for imaging purposes and will be taken out in future.
   .
   # CAD/NSTEMI - NSTEMI at OSH with troponin peak at 0.76 on [**10-27**],
   trending down since, prior ECG changes with diffuse precordial T wave
   inversion, now improved.
   - Cardiology had been following, recommended medical management (ASA,
   low-dose B-Blocker if BP tolerates, Statin, Plavix, holding ACEi given
   ARF, hypotension)
   .
   # Acute diastolic CHF - Potentially NSTEMI precipitated or infection,
   now likely clinically euvolemic. BNP drawn with AM labs.
   - Will discuss possible trial of diuresis today, however creatinine did
   bump from 1.1 to 1.3 overnight.
   - CXR overall unchanged.
   - Last echo as noted above.
   - Attempting to see if possible to concentrate medications to lessen
   IVF load.
   .
   # ARF- This morning creatinine 1.3, which is a bump from yesterday
   1.1. Previously had bumpted to 1.4, likely secondary to diuresis
   - Will continue to follow trend.
   .
   # Heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan - Consider ultrasound to further
   characterize, once more stable or as outpatient.
   - TSH 0.51 on [**11-1**]
   .
   # Anemia: HCT dipped down today to 25. Over last weeks to month, has
   been 26-29. Iron Studies indicative of Anemia of Chronic Disease given
   advanced ca; no evidence of acute bleeding.
   - Folate, TSH, B-12 all within normal limits.
   - Will check PM HCT to ensure it is stable.
   .
   # DM2: FSBG have been running high since last night (300
s-400
   Suspect secondary to increased steroid dose, also possibly related to
   infection. Glargine was increased last night to 40 units.
   - Given ability to improve control while patient remains in ICU, will
   initiated insulin gtt.
   .
   #. FEN - Cardiac, diabetic diet. Will replete electrolytes as needed.
   .
   #. Communication - Wife, [**Name (NI) 2856**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5547**], and son [**Name (NI) 2667**] [**Name (NI) **]
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5548**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Diabetic, cardiac
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin gtt.
   Lines:
   PIVs x2
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  Heparin SQ
   Stress ulcer:  On PPI for hx GERD as well.
   VAP:  N/A
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code currently, patient still thinking over
   options
will try to re-address with wife today, oncologist.
   Disposition: ICU until respiratory status improved.

   . Recent changes over four days documented by conventional chest

   as a
   first step.
   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 79 yo M with PMH DM2, interstitial lung disease,
   diastolic CHF, CAD s/p NSTEMI with recent diagnosis of unresectable
   cholangiocarcinoma s/p CBD excision, cholecystectomy, lymph node bx,
   PTC placement and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, with no further
   surgical management, transferred to MICU for hypoxia.
   .
   # Hypoxia
 Patient continues to be on non-rebreather for the better
   part of yesterday. High resolution chest CT yesterday was suspicious
   for pulmonary edema in setting of underlying interstitial lung disease.
   It is still likely that the cause of his hypoxia is likely
   multifactorial due to possible pulmonary infection (purlent sputum,
   fevers), ILD exacerbation in setting of prednisone being tapered, and
   acute diastolic CHF exacerbation.
   .
   He continues to appear rather euvolemic on exam. We are continuing
   treatment for PCP in the setting of his elevated LDH and long-term
   steroid use and CT that could be consistent with this.  Less likely is
   lymphangitic spread of carcinoma.- Patient just completed 7 days of
   levofloxacin (day 1 = [**2138-10-27**])
   - Ordered induced sputum culture for PCP stain as well, given that the
   only negative PCP stain is from a sample that was contaminated.
   Currently patient appears too tenuous to bronch at present.
   - Initiate steroid treatment for PCP yesterday, which will also treat
   his intersitial lung disease, if this is playing role. Plan will be for
   prednisone 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] for 5 days (day 1 = [**11-3**]), 40 mg daily for 5 days,
   then 20 mg for 11 days. Initiated [**Month/Year (2) **] IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]) for PCP
   treatment as well.
   - Initiated vancomycin and zosyn today for hospital acquired PNA (day 1
   = [**11-4**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed
   - Continue attempt to wean O2, to keep sat >92%
   - Incentive Spirometry
   - Creatinine bumped since yesterday, but given CT appearance, will
   discuss trial of lasix to see if patient is able to come off
   non-rebreather
   .
   # Fever, leukocytosis: Resolved from yesterday, when there had been
   concern for infection in setting of low grade temp and leukocytosis.
   Continuing to monitor for infection (possible sources including urinary
   given foley, lung given hypoxia, and GI given percutaneous drain).
   - Will follow up culture data, antibiotics as noted above should also
   cover gram negative pathogens from GU/GI tract.
   .
   # Hypotension
 Yesterday had transient hypotension (80
s), which was
   asymptomatic. The etiology is unclear, but could be likely be
   multifactorial with differential diagnosis including intravascularly
   depleted vs adrenal insufficiency in setting of long term steroid use
   vs diabetic autonomic dysfunction. Yesterday concern was for possibly
   brewing sepsis, but resolved today. Will consider tolerating if
   mentating, making urine, asymptomatic and MAP >55-60.
   - Goal SBP >100
   - AM cortisol was 24.5 on [**11-2**]
   - Diuresis as needed for respiratory state and tolerated by blood
   pressure.
   - Stress dose steroids given this morning given history of use and
   recent taper.
   - Holding lisinopril given recent creatinine bump.
   - If possible, once more stable, will consider addition of low dose
   metoprolol given recent NSTEMI if tolerated by bp
   .
   # Cholangio CA, biliary stricture - Curative surgery not possible,
   reconstruction with roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy performed in [**Month (only) 705**]
   [**2138**].
   - Follow-up as outpatient with oncology
   - Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 511**]
s team will see patient today to help guide
   recommendations for drain.
   .
   # CAD/NSTEMI - NSTEMI at OSH with troponin peak at 0.76 on [**10-27**],
   trending down since, prior ECG changes with diffuse precordial T wave
   inversion, now improved.
   - Cardiology had been following, recommended medical management (ASA,
   low-dose B-Blocker if BP tolerates, Statin, Plavix, holding ACEi given
   ARF, hypotension)
   .
   # Acute diastolic CHF - Potentially NSTEMI precipitated or infection,
   now likely clinically euvolemic. BNP drawn with AM labs.
   - Will discuss possible trial of diuresis today, however creatinine did
   bump from 1.1 to 1.3 overnight.
   - CXR pending from this morning.
   - Last echo as noted above.
   .
   # ARF- This morning creatinine 1.3, which is a bump from yesterday
   1.1. Previously had bumpted to 1.4, likely secondary to diuresis
   - Discussing possible additional diuresis today.
   .
   # Heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan - Consider ultrasound to further
   characterize, once more stable or as outpatient.
   - TSH 0.51 on [**11-1**]
   .
   # Anemia: HCT dipped down today to 25. Over last weeks to month, has
   been 26-29. Iron Studies indicative of Anemia of Chronic Disease given
   advanced ca; no evidence of acute bleeding.
   - Folate, TSH, B-12 all within normal limits.
   - Will check PM HCT to ensure it is stable.
   .
   # DM2: FSBG have been running high since last night (300
s-400
   Suspect secondary to increased steroid dose, also possibly related to
   infection.
   - Will plan to increase PM glargine and humalog sliding scale.
   .
   #. FEN - Cardiac, diabetic diet. Will replete electrolytes as needed.
   .
   #. Communication - Wife, [**Name (NI) 2856**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5547**], and son [**Name (NI) 2667**] [**Name (NI) **]
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5548**]

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 79 yo M with PMH DM2, interstitial lung disease,
   diastolic CHF, CAD s/p NSTEMI with recent diagnosis of unresectable
   cholangiocarcinoma s/p CBD excision, cholecystectomy, lymph node bx,
   PTC placement and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, with no further
   surgical management, transferred to MICU for hypoxia.
   .
   # Hypoxia
 Patient continues to be on non-rebreather for the better
   part of yesterday. High resolution chest CT yesterday was suspicious
   for pulmonary edema in setting of underlying interstitial lung disease.
   It is still likely that the cause of his hypoxia is likely
   multifactorial due to possible pulmonary infection (purlent sputum,
   fevers), ILD exacerbation in setting of prednisone being tapered, and
   acute diastolic CHF exacerbation.
   .
   He continues to appear rather euvolemic on exam. We are continuing
   treatment for PCP in the setting of his elevated LDH and long-term
   steroid use and CT that could be consistent with this.  Less likely is
   lymphangitic spread of carcinoma.- Patient just completed 7 days of
   levofloxacin (day 1 = [**2138-10-27**])
   - Ordered induced sputum culture for PCP stain as well, given that the
   only negative PCP stain is from a sample that was contaminated.
   Currently patient appears too tenuous to bronch at present.
   - Initiate steroid treatment for PCP yesterday, which will also treat
   his intersitial lung disease, if this is playing role. Plan will be for
   prednisone 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] for 5 days (day 1 = [**11-3**]), 40 mg daily for 5 days,
   then 20 mg for 11 days. Initiated [**Month/Year (2) **] IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]) for PCP
   treatment as well.
   - Initiated vancomycin and zosyn today for hospital acquired PNA (day 1
   = [**11-4**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed
   - Continue attempt to wean O2, to keep sat >92%
   - Incentive Spirometry
   - Creatinine bumped since yesterday, but given CT appearance, will
   discuss trial of lasix to see if patient is able to come off
   non-rebreather
   .
   # Fever, leukocytosis: Resolved from yesterday, when there had been
   concern for infection in setting of low grade temp and leukocytosis.
   Continuing to monitor for infection (possible sources including urinary
   given foley, lung given hypoxia, and GI given percutaneous drain).
   - Will follow up culture data, antibiotics as noted above should also
   cover gram negative pathogens from GU/GI tract.
   .
   # Hypotension
 Yesterday had transient hypotension (80
s), which was
   asymptomatic. The etiology is unclear, but could be likely be
   multifactorial with differential diagnosis including intravascularly
   depleted vs adrenal insufficiency in setting of long term steroid use
   vs diabetic autonomic dysfunction. Yesterday concern was for possibly
   brewing sepsis, but resolved today. Will consider tolerating if
   mentating, making urine, asymptomatic and MAP >55-60.
   - Goal SBP >100
   - AM cortisol was 24.5 on [**11-2**]
   - Diuresis as needed for respiratory state and tolerated by blood
   pressure.
   - Stress dose steroids given this morning given history of use and
   recent taper.
   - Holding lisinopril given recent creatinine bump.
   - If possible, once more stable, will consider addition of low dose
   metoprolol given recent NSTEMI if tolerated by bp
   .
   # Cholangio CA, biliary stricture - Curative surgery not possible,
   reconstruction with roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy performed in [**Month (only) 705**]
   [**2138**].
   - Follow-up as outpatient with oncology
   - Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 511**]
s team will see patient today to help guide
   recommendations for drain.
   .
   # CAD/NSTEMI - NSTEMI at OSH with troponin peak at 0.76 on [**10-27**],
   trending down since, prior ECG changes with diffuse precordial T wave
   inversion, now improved.
   - Cardiology had been following, recommended medical management (ASA,
   low-dose B-Blocker if BP tolerates, Statin, Plavix, holding ACEi given
   ARF, hypotension)
   .
   # Acute diastolic CHF - Potentially NSTEMI precipitated or infection,
   now likely clinically euvolemic. BNP drawn with AM labs.
   - Will discuss possible trial of diuresis today, however creatinine did
   bump from 1.1 to 1.3 overnight.
   - CXR pending from this morning.
   - Last echo as noted above.
   .
   # ARF- This morning creatinine 1.3, which is a bump from yesterday
   1.1. Previously had bumpted to 1.4, likely secondary to diuresis
   - Discussing possible additional diuresis today.
   .
   # Heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan - Consider ultrasound to further
   characterize, once more stable or as outpatient.
   - TSH 0.51 on [**11-1**]
   .
   # Anemia: HCT dipped down today to 25. Over last weeks to month, has
   been 26-29. Iron Studies indicative of Anemia of Chronic Disease given
   advanced ca; no evidence of acute bleeding.
   - Folate, TSH, B-12 all within normal limits.
   - Will check PM HCT to ensure it is stable.
   .
   # DM2: FSBG have been running high since last night (300
s-400
   Suspect secondary to increased steroid dose, also possibly related to
   infection.
   - Will plan to increase PM glargine and humalog sliding scale.
   .
   #. FEN - Cardiac, diabetic diet. Will replete electrolytes as needed.
   .
   #. Communication - Wife, [**Name (NI) 2856**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5547**], and son [**Name (NI) 2667**] [**Name (NI) **]

Summary:

The patient, a 79-year-old male, is being treated in the ICU for hypoxia, fever, and leukocytosis. He has a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was recently diagnosed with probable PCP and is being treated with prednisone and antibiotics. He has also been diagnosed with acute diastolic congestive heart failure, acute kidney injury, and anemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's high-resolution chest CT scan shows worsening reticular and ground-glass abnormalities, which could be due to pulmonary edema. This could lead to further respiratory distress and hypoxia.
2. Infection: The patient's fever, leukocytosis, and contaminated sputum cultures suggest that he may have an underlying infection. This could lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
3. Acute Diastolic Congestive Heart Failure: The patient's recent diagnosis of acute diastolic congestive heart failure could lead to further cardiac compromise and worsening of his respiratory status.
4. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's increasing creatinine levels suggest that he may be experiencing acute kidney injury. This could lead to further electrolyte imbalances and fluid overload.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia could lead to further respiratory distress and decreased oxygen delivery to his tissues.
6. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension could be due to a variety of factors, including sepsis, cardiac compromise, and dehydration. This could lead to further organ dysfunction and decreased perfusion to his tissues.
7. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's recent diagnosis of unresectable cholangiocarcinoma and his history of percutaneous drain placement increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his oxygen therapy as needed.
2. Continue to treat the patient's suspected PCP infection with antibiotics and prednisone.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his diuretic therapy as needed to manage his acute diastolic congestive heart failure.
4. Monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust his fluid and electrolyte therapy as needed to manage his acute kidney injury.
5. Consider ordering additional tests, such as a cardiac echo and a thyroid ultrasound, to further characterize the patient's cardiac and thyroid status.
6. Consider adjusting the patient's medication regimen to better manage his anemia and hypotension.
7. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust his anticoagulation therapy as needed to manage his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, and coronary artery disease. He was recently diagnosed with unresectable cholangiocarcinoma and underwent surgery, including CBD excision, cholecystectomy, lymph node biopsy, PTC placement, and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy. He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia, which has been treated with oxygen therapy. His anemia is being managed with transfusions.

The patient is being treated empirically for Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP) due to his long-term steroid use and CT findings. He has been prescribed prednisone, Bactrim, and vancomycin. His fever, leukocytosis, and hypotension have resolved.

The patient's condition is complicated by his history of NSTEMI, which led to a recent diagnosis of unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He has also been diagnosed with acute diastolic congestive heart failure, which is being managed with medical therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient is at risk for pneumonia due to his immunocompromised state and recent surgery.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever, leukocytosis, and hypotension suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could be caused by a variety of pathogens.
3. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's history of NSTEMI and recent surgery put him at risk for pulmonary embolism.
4. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient's high blood glucose levels and recent increase in insulin dose put him at risk for diabetic ketoacidosis.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient's recent increase in insulin dose and high blood glucose levels put him at risk for hypoglycemia.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of NSTEMI and diastolic congestive heart failure put him at risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
7. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and recent surgery put him at risk for infection, which could be caused by a variety of pathogens.
8. Bleeding: The patient's history of NSTEMI and recent surgery put him at risk for bleeding, which could be caused by a variety of factors.
9. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's history of NSTEMI and recent surgery put him at risk for thrombocytopenia, which could be caused by a variety of factors.
10. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's history of NSTEMI and recent surgery put him at risk for electrolyte imbalances, which could be caused by a variety of factors.

 Patient continued to be on non-rebreather for the better
   part of yesterday. This morning he was transitioned to a high-flow mask
   and is impoved on that. Read of high resolution chest CT yesterday was
   suspicious for pulmonary edema in setting of underlying interstitial
   lung disease, however overall picture is more consistent with an
   atypical infection or PCP in setting of his interstitial lung disease.
   Will not purse further diuresis given he overall appears euvolemic and
   had hypotension after diuresis yesterday.  We are continuing treatment
   for PCP in the setting of his elevated LDH and long-term steroid use
   and CT that could be consistent with this.  Less likely is lymphangitic
   spread of carcinoma.- Patient just completed 7 days of levofloxacin

   his intersitial lung disease, if this is playing role. Plan will be for
   prednisone 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] for 5 days (day 1 = [**11-3**]), 40 mg daily for 5 days,
   then 20 mg for 11 days. Initiated Bactrim IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]) for PCP
   treatment as well.

s outpatient

   presented several years ago and had diffuse changes on CT (ground
   glass, fibrosis). The patient was initially treated with high dose
   steroids, then quickly tapered down to maintance dose (2.5-10 mg per
   reports).  A bronchosocpy was never completed per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5568**]
s report.
   This would likely be helpful for additional work up, but patient
   remains too tenuous to bronch at present.

   (day 1 = [**2138-10-27**])
   - Ordered induced sputum culture for PCP stain as well, given that the
   only negative PCP stain is from a sample that was contaminated.
   Currently patient appears too tenuous to bronch at present.
   - Initiate steroid treatment for PCP yesterday, which will also treat
   his intersitial lung disease, if this is playing role. Plan will be for
   prednisone 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] for 5 days (day 1 = [**11-3**]), 40 mg daily for 5 days,
   then 20 mg for 11 days. Initiated Bactrim IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]) for PCP
   treatment as well.
   - Initiated vancomycin and zosyn today for hospital acquired PNA (day 1
   = [**11-4**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed
   - Continue attempt to wean O2, to keep sat >92%
   - Will hold off PFTs as not likely to be helpful in setting of acute
   decompensation.
   - ICU fellow [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 955**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 90**] discussed case with patient
s outpatient
   pulmonologist, Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5568**]. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5568**] reported that the patient had
   presented several years ago and had diffuse changes on CT (ground
   glass, fibrosis). The patient was initially treated with high dose
   steroids, then quickly tapered down to maintance dose (2.5-10 mg per
   reports).  A bronchosocpy was never completed per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5568**]
s report.
   This would likely be helpful for additional work up, but patient
   remains too tenuous to bronch at present.
   # Fever, leukocytosis: Resolved from yesterday, when there had been
   concern for infection in setting of low grade temp and leukocytosis.
   Continuing to monitor for infection (possible sources including urinary
   given foley, lung given hypoxia, and GI given percutaneous drain).
   - Will follow up culture data, antibiotics as noted above should also
   cover gram negative pathogens from GU/GI tract.
   # Hypotension
 Yesterday had transient hypotension (80
s), which was
   asymptomatic. This episode was likely secondary to his diruesis after
   the lasix he received. His borderline low BP remains likely
   multifactorial with differential diagnosis including intravascularly
   depleted vs adrenal insufficiency in setting of long term steroid use
   vs diabetic autonomic dysfunction. Yesterday concern was for possibly
   brewing sepsis, but resolved today. Will consider tolerating if
   mentating, making urine, asymptomatic and MAP >55-60.
   - Goal SBP >100
   - AM cortisol was 24.5 on [**11-2**], on steroids [**Hospital1 **] for above reasons.
   - Holding lisinopril given recent creatinine bump.
   - If possible, once more stable, will consider addition of low dose
   metoprolol given recent NSTEMI if tolerated by bp
   # Cholangio CA, biliary stricture - Curative surgery not possible,
   reconstruction with roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy performed in [**Month (only) 705**]
   [**2138**].
   - Follow-up as outpatient with oncology
will try to reach patient
   primary oncologist today to further discuss his prognosis to help
   further discuss goals of care and how aggressively to further work up
   and treat his pulmonary process.
   - Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 511**]
s team will see patient today to help guide
   recommendations for drain, appreciate assistance. Tube is in place
   mainly for imaging purposes and will be taken out in future.
   # CAD/NSTEMI - NSTEMI at OSH with troponin peak at 0.76 on [**10-27**],
   trending down since, prior ECG changes with diffuse precordial T wave
   inversion, now improved.
   - Cardiology had been following, recommended medical management (ASA,
   low-dose B-Blocker if BP tolerates, Statin, Plavix, holding ACEi given
   ARF, hypotension)
   # Acute diastolic CHF - Potentially NSTEMI precipitated or infection,
   now likely clinically euvolemic. BNP drawn with AM labs.
   - Will discuss possible trial of diuresis today, however creatinine did
   bump from 1.1 to 1.3 overnight.
   - CXR overall unchanged.
   - Last echo as noted above.
   - Attempting to see if possible to concentrate medications to lessen
   IVF load.
   # ARF- This morning creatinine 1.3, which is a bump from yesterday
   1.1. Previously had bumpted to 1.4, likely secondary to diuresis
   - Will continue to follow trend.
   # Heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan - Consider ultrasound to further
   characterize, once more stable or as outpatient.
   - TSH 0.51 on [**11-1**]
   # Anemia: HCT dipped down today to 25. Over last weeks to month, has
   been 26-29. Iron Studies indicative of Anemia of Chronic Disease given
   advanced ca; no evidence of acute bleeding.
   - Folate, TSH, B-12 all within normal limits.
   - Will check PM HCT to ensure it is stable.
   # DM2: FSBG have been running high since last night (300
s-400
   Suspect secondary to increased steroid dose, also possibly related to
   infection. Glargine was increased last night to 40 units.
   - Given ability to improve control while patient remains in ICU, will
   initiated insulin gtt.
   #. FEN - Cardiac, diabetic diet. Will replete electrolytes as needed.
   #. Communication - Wife, [**Name (NI) 2856**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5547**], and son [**Name (NI) 2667**] [**Name (NI) **]

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of diabetes, interstitial lung disease, diastolic CHF, CAD, and recent diagnosis of unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was transferred to the ICU for hypoxia and is currently being treated for possible PCP infection. He has a history of long-term steroid use, which may be contributing to his current condition. He has been diagnosed with ARF, anemia, and DM2.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia and possible PCP infection may lead to respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated LDH and WBC count suggest the possibility of sepsis, which may be exacerbated by his underlying conditions.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of CAD and recent NSTEMI may lead to cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac arrest.
4. Infection: The patient's history of long-term steroid use and possible PCP infection may increase his risk of infection.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
6. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient's DM2 and recent increase in steroid dose may lead to diabetic ketoacidosis.
7. Fluid overload: The patient's history of CHF and recent diuresis may lead to fluid overload, which may worsen his respiratory and cardiac conditions.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's percutaneous drain and history of cholecystectomy may increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding or obstruction.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is being closely monitored, and his treatment plan includes antibiotics for possible PCP infection, steroids for interstitial lung disease, and diuresis for CHF. His insulin gtt has been initiated to manage his DM2, and his electrolytes are being repleted as needed. The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is unclear at this time.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of interstitial lung disease (ILD), diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF), recent non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma, admitted with hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation and has been treated with antibiotics, antifungals, and steroids.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may be due to an underlying infection, such as atypical pneumonia or Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP), or exacerbation of his ILD. The patient's oxygen saturation is 95%, but his respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, which may indicate underlying respiratory distress.
2. Infection: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and he has been treated with antibiotics and antifungals. However, the patient's creatinine level is increasing, which may indicate kidney damage due to infection.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, which may be due to the steroids he is receiving or an underlying infection.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is 92/62 mmHg, which is low. This may be due to the patient's underlying heart failure or sepsis.
5. CHF/CAD: The patient has a history of CHF and CAD, and his ejection fraction is not mentioned. His blood pressure is low, which may indicate underlying heart failure.
6. Elevated creatinine: The patient's creatinine level is increasing, which may indicate kidney damage due to infection, sepsis, or underlying kidney disease.
7. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, which may be due to underlying bleeding or bone marrow suppression.
8. Diabetes: The patient has a history of diabetes and is receiving insulin and a sliding scale. His glucose level is improving, but he may still be at risk for hyperglycemia.
9. ICU-acquired complications: The patient is at risk for ICU-acquired complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, central line-associated bloodstream infection, and pressure ulcers.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his mechanical ventilation settings as needed.
2. Consider adding antiviral therapy for atypical pneumonia or PCP if the patient's respiratory failure persists.
3. Continue to treat the patient's infection with antibiotics and antifungals, and consider adding additional antibiotics if the patient's infection is not responding to treatment.
4. Monitor the patient's white blood cell count and consider adjusting his steroid dose if his leukocytosis persists.
5. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and consider adding vasopressors if his blood pressure remains low.
6. Consider adding diuretics to the patient's medication regimen to help manage his CHF.
7. Monitor the patient's creatinine level and consider adding additional medications to help manage his kidney function.
8. Consider transfusing the patient with packed red blood cells if his hemoglobin level remains low.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's glucose level and adjust his insulin regimen as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-inch tall individual who was admitted to the ICU with a poor prognosis. Over the past 24 hours, they received 1 unit of blood transfusion, 20 IV Lasix, and pulse steroids (Solumedrol 250 qid x 3d). They were also started on various medications, including antibiotics, insulin, and heparin. The patient's vital signs remain stable, with a temperature of 36.6C, heart rate of 75 bpm, and blood pressure of 117/61 mmHg. They are receiving high-flow oxygen and have a SpO2 of 92%. The patient's labs show a white blood cell count of 13.4, hemoglobin of 8.3 g/dL, and platelet count of 346 K/uL. They have also had various cultures taken, including blood cultures, sputum culture, and urine culture, with no growth reported.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's blood cultures were negative, but they did have a fever and tachycardia, which could be indicative of sepsis.
2. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient is at risk for pulmonary embolism due to their poor prognosis and immobility.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's SpO2 is 92%, which may indicate early signs of respiratory failure.
4. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's code status is full code, which means they are at risk for cardiac arrest.
5. Bleeding Complications: The patient is receiving heparin and has a platelet count of 346 K/uL, which may increase their risk of bleeding complications.
6. Infection: The patient's sputum culture was contaminated, and their urine culture was negative, but they may still be at risk for infection.
7. Fluid Overload: The patient has received 2,760 mL of fluid over the past 24 hours, which may lead to fluid overload.
8. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's labs show an imbalance in their electrolytes, including potassium, magnesium, and phosphate.
9. Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level is 1.1 mg/dL, which may indicate early signs of renal failure.
10. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's lab results show an elevated troponin-T level, which may indicate gastrointestinal bleeding.

These potential complications will require close monitoring and management to prevent or treat them effectively.

   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 79 yo M with PMH DM2, interstitial lung disease,
   diastolic CHF, CAD s/p NSTEMI with recent diagnosis of unresectable
   cholangiocarcinoma s/p CBD excision, cholecystectomy, lymph node bx,
   PTC placement and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, with no further
   surgical management, transferred to MICU for hypoxia, feeling well but
   remaining hypoxic.
   Hypoxia:  Patient remains on 100% high-flow mask. Subjectively he feels
   his breathing has improved. Prior CT chest suspicious for pulmonary
   edema in setting of ILD, but clinical picture is consistent with an
   atypical infection or PCP. [**Name10 (NameIs) 1204**] lack of improvement to treatment for
   hospital-acquired pneumonia and PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) 5604**] pulse dose steroids
   yesterday to treat possible exacerbation of his interstitial lung
   disease. Will continue to monitor over next 24 hrs, as would expect
   some improvement in oxygen need if steroids are helping. No evidence of
   fluid overload on exam, continues to be negative balance for I/O
   - Patient s/p 7 days of levofloxacin (day 1 = [**2138-10-27**])
   - PCP negative in sputum x1, but poor sputum samples
   - Continue 3 weeks of empiric PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) **]:
   - On [**11-3**], had [**Month/Year (2) 5604**] prednisone 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] for 5 days (day 1 =
   [**11-3**]), 40 mg daily for 5 days, then 20 mg for 11 days.  Yesterday
   started methylprednisolone 250 mg IV TID for three days.
   - Bactrim IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]), today is day 4, was changed to PO
   yesterday to limit fluid loads.
   - Continue vancomycin and zosyn today for hospital acquired PNA (day 1
   = [**11-3**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed
   - Continue attempt to wean O2, to keep sat >92%
   - Transfused 1 unit yesterday for low HCT, followed by lasix.
   - Biospy or bronchoscopy would be helpful to help guide diagnosis and
   management, however patient
s respiratory status is too tenuous
   currently, and bronchoscopy would likely lead to intubation, and
   concern is that patient would not be able to be extubated.
   Anemia: Improved this AM after yesterday
s transfusion. Etiology still
   remains unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 59**] reported bloody stool or emesis. Maybe hemolysis,
   bactrim related marrow [**Last Name (LF) 5587**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be cancer related.
   - Monitoring stook guaiac,
   - Hemolysis labs have not been consistent with hemolysis
   Leukocytosis: In setting of steroids, stable. Continuing to monitor for
   infection (possible sources including urinary given foley, lung given
   hypoxia, and GI given percutaneous drain).
   - f/u culture data, antibiotics as noted above should also cover gram
   negative pathogens from GU/GI tract.
   Hypotension:  Resolved. Hypotension in past has been in setting of
   diuresis. AM cortisol was 24.5 on [**11-2**], on steroids [**Hospital1 **] for above
   reasons.
   - Holding lisinopril and BB given borderline pressures.
   Cholangio CA, biliary stricture: Curative surgery not possible,
   reconstruction with roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy performed in [**Month (only) 705**]
   [**2138**].
   - Appreciate oncology input re: prognosis to help further discuss goals
   of care and how aggressively to further work up and treat his pulmonary
   process.
   - Per Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 511**]
s team tube is in place mainly for imaging purposes
   and will be taken out in future. Appreciate input
   CAD/NSTEMI: NSTEMI at OSH with troponin peak at 0.76 on [**10-27**], prior ECG
   changes with diffuse precordial T wave inversion, now improved.
   - Cardiology imput appreciated: recommended medical management (ASA,
   low-dose B-Blocker if BP tolerates, Statin, Plavix, holding ACEi given
   ARF, hypotension)
   Acute diastolic CHF: Potentially NSTEMI precipitated or infection, now
   likely clinically euvolemic. No RV pathology in recent ECHO from last
   week.
   - CXR overall unchanged.
   - Attempting to see if possible to concentrate medications to lessen
   IVF load.
   ARF: Resolved. Creatinine 1.1, from 1.3 yesterday, highest had been 1.4
   in setting of diuresis .
   - Will continue to follow trend.
   Heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan: Consider ultrasound to further
   characterize as outpatient.
   - TSH 0.51 on [**11-1**]
   DM2: FSBG have been running high since transfer up to 300-400. Suspect
   secondary to increased steroid dose, also possibly related to
   infection. FSBG was slightly low yesterday and this AM, so [**Month/Year (2) 3973**] was
   reduced to home dose of 20 units. Elevated insulin needs earlier in
   week may have been due to stress of transfer, possibly infection, but
   with increased steroid dose, this does not seen to be a problem
   currently.
   - [**Name2 (NI) **] and humalog sliding scale.
   FEN: Cardiac, diabetic diet. Will replete electrolytes as needed.
   Communication: Wife, [**Name (NI) 2856**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5547**], and son [**Name (NI) 2667**] [**Name (NI) **]
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5548**]
   ICU Care

   Cardiac and diabetic diet.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Unresectable cholangiocarcinoma

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU until his respiratory status improves.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma.
* He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to hypoxia, anemia, and potential infection.
* His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6C (97.8F), heart rate of 75 beats per minute, blood pressure of 117/61 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 92%.
* He is receiving oxygen therapy via a high-flow nebulizer and has a tracheostomy tube in place for imaging purposes.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* **Infection:** The patient is at risk for developing a secondary infection, particularly in the respiratory, urinary, and gastrointestinal tracts. The patient's history of long-term steroid use and recent surgery increases his risk for infection.
* **Anemia:** The patient's anemia may be contributing to his hypoxia, and further investigation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
* **Hypotension:** The patient's history of hypotension in the past, particularly during diuresis, increases his risk for future episodes.
* **Cardiac Complications:** The patient's history of coronary artery disease and recent NSTEMI increases his risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias and heart failure.
* **Pulmonary Complications:** The patient's history of interstitial lung disease and recent surgery increases his risk for pulmonary complications, such as pneumonia and respiratory failure.
* **Gastrointestinal Complications:** The patient's history of recent surgery and potential infection increases his risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding and perforation.

**Assessment and Plan:**

* The patient's diagnosis of probable PCP is being treated empirically with prednisone, Bactrim, and vancomycin.
* The patient's anemia is being treated with blood transfusions, and further investigation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
* The patient's hypotension is being monitored closely, and further management is needed to prevent future episodes.
* The patient's cardiac condition is being managed with medical therapy, and further investigation is needed to determine the optimal treatment plan.
* The patient's pulmonary condition is being managed with oxygen therapy and further investigation is needed to determine the optimal treatment plan.
* The patient's gastrointestinal condition is being monitored closely, and further investigation is needed to determine the optimal treatment plan.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for developing further medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic heart failure, and coronary artery disease, who has been admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and feeling well but remaining hypoxic. He has been on oxygen therapy for several days and has been experiencing difficulty breathing, with a recent increase in oxygen requirements. He has also been experiencing intermittent coughing and has been on antibiotics for possible pneumonia.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 64 beats per minute, blood pressure of 129/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94% on 100% oxygen. His respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and his temperature is 36.3C.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 13.4 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 7.9 g/dL, and platelet count of 329 x 10^9/L. His liver function tests are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) of 34 IU/L and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) of 12 IU/L. His creatinine level is 1.1 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 27 mg/dL.

The patient's medications include insulin, metoprolol, simvastatin, and aspirin, as well as antibiotics and antifungal agents. He is also receiving oxygen therapy and has been given a tracheostomy tube.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia and difficulty breathing may progress to respiratory failure, which could lead to intubation and mechanical ventilation.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's intermittent coughing and fever may indicate pneumonia, which could worsen his respiratory status and increase the risk of respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of coronary artery disease and diastolic heart failure may increase his risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac arrest.
4. Infection: The patient's antibiotics and antifungal agents may not be effective against the underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis or organ failure.
5. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient's bleeding disorder and recent surgery may increase his risk of hemorrhagic complications, such as bleeding from the gastrointestinal tract or intracranial bleeding.
6. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine level and BUN level may indicate renal failure, which could worsen his overall condition and increase his risk of complications.
7. Metabolic complications: The patient's diabetes and history of hypoglycemia may increase his risk of metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.

Recommendations:

1. Continue oxygen therapy and monitor the patient's respiratory status closely.
2. Consider bronchoscopy or biopsy to help guide diagnosis and management of the patient's respiratory infection.
3. Continue antibiotics and antifungal agents, and monitor the patient's response to treatment.
4. Consider cardiac evaluation to assess the patient's cardiac status and risk of cardiac complications.
5. Monitor the patient's bleeding disorder and bleeding risk, and consider transfusion of blood products as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's renal function and consider dialysis if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's metabolic status and adjust his insulin therapy as necessary to prevent hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a complex medical history. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3C, heart rate of 64 bpm, blood pressure of 129/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94%. The patient is receiving respiratory support with high-flow nasal oxygen and has a SpO2 of 94%. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a normal cardiac rhythm and adequate blood pressure.

The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, insulin, and heparin, and has had multiple lab tests and imaging studies performed. The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, blood urea nitrogen, and creatinine, indicating potential kidney and liver dysfunction.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to their critical condition, but they are responsive to stimuli and have a normal cardiac rhythm. The patient's neurologic examination is also limited, but they are able to move and respond to stimuli.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and blood urea nitrogen levels suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's elevated creatinine levels and decreased blood urea nitrogen levels indicate potential AKI, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
3. Liver Dysfunction: The patient's elevated liver enzymes and decreased albumin levels suggest potential liver dysfunction, which can lead to coagulopathy and bleeding.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's need for high-flow nasal oxygen and potential respiratory acidosis suggest the possibility of respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
5. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension suggest potential cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
6. Neurologic Complications: The patient's limited neurologic examination and potential sepsis suggest the possibility of neurologic complications, such as stroke or encephalopathy.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's potential stress ulcer and gastrointestinal bleeding suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal complications, such as perforation or obstruction.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor their vital signs, lab results, and physical examination findings to identify potential complications early and initiate appropriate interventions to prevent or treat them.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 79 yo M with PMH DM2, interstitial lung disease,
   diastolic CHF, CAD s/p NSTEMI with recent diagnosis of unresectable
   cholangiocarcinoma s/p CBD excision, cholecystectomy, lymph node bx,
   PTC placement and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, with no further
   surgical management, transferred to MICU for hypoxia, feeling well but
   remaining hypoxic.
   Hypoxia:  Patient remains on 100% high-flow mask. Subjectively he feels
   his breathing has improved. Prior CT chest suspicious for pulmonary
   edema in setting of ILD, but clinical picture is consistent with an
   atypical infection or PCP. [**Name10 (NameIs) 1204**] lack of improvement to treatment for
   hospital-acquired pneumonia and PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) 5604**] pulse dose steroids
   yesterday to treat possible exacerbation of his interstitial lung
   disease. Will continue to monitor over next 24 hrs, as would expect
   some improvement in oxygen need if steroids are helping. No evidence of
   fluid overload on exam, continues to be negative balance for I/O
   - Patient s/p 7 days of levofloxacin (day 1 = [**2138-10-27**])
   - PCP negative in sputum x1, but poor sputum samples
   - Continue 3 weeks of empiric PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) **]:
   - On [**11-3**], had [**Month/Year (2) 5604**] prednisone 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] for 5 days (day 1 =
   [**11-3**]), 40 mg daily for 5 days, then 20 mg for 11 days.  Yesterday
   started methylprednisolone 250 mg IV TID for three days.
   - Bactrim IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]), today is day 4, was changed to PO
   yesterday to limit fluid loads.
   - Continue vancomycin and zosyn today for hospital acquired PNA (day 1
   = [**11-3**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed
   - Continue attempt to wean O2, to keep sat >92%
   - Transfused 1 unit yesterday for low HCT, followed by lasix.
   - Biospy or bronchoscopy would be helpful to help guide diagnosis and
   management, however patient
s respiratory status is too tenuous
   currently, and bronchoscopy would likely lead to intubation, and
   concern is that patient would not be able to be extubated.
   Anemia: Improved this AM after yesterday
s transfusion. Etiology still
   remains unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 59**] reported bloody stool or emesis. Maybe hemolysis,
   bactrim related marrow [**Last Name (LF) 5587**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be cancer related.
   - Monitoring stook guaiac,
   - Hemolysis labs have not been consistent with hemolysis
   Leukocytosis: In setting of steroids, stable. Continuing to monitor for
   infection (possible sources including urinary given foley, lung given
   hypoxia, and GI given percutaneous drain).
   - f/u culture data, antibiotics as noted above should also cover gram
   negative pathogens from GU/GI tract.
   Hypotension:  Resolved. Hypotension in past has been in setting of
   diuresis. AM cortisol was 24.5 on [**11-2**], on steroids [**Hospital1 **] for above
   reasons.
   - Holding lisinopril and BB given borderline pressures.
   Cholangio CA, biliary stricture: Curative surgery not possible,
   reconstruction with roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy performed in [**Month (only) 705**]
   [**2138**].
   - Appreciate oncology input re: prognosis to help further discuss goals
   of care and how aggressively to further work up and treat his pulmonary
   process.
   - Per Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 511**]
s team tube is in place mainly for imaging purposes
   and will be taken out in future. Appreciate input
   CAD/NSTEMI: NSTEMI at OSH with troponin peak at 0.76 on [**10-27**], prior ECG
   changes with diffuse precordial T wave inversion, now improved.
   - Cardiology imput appreciated: recommended medical management (ASA,
   low-dose B-Blocker if BP tolerates, Statin, Plavix, holding ACEi given
   ARF, hypotension)
   Acute diastolic CHF: Potentially NSTEMI precipitated or infection, now
   likely clinically euvolemic. No RV pathology in recent ECHO from last
   week.
   - CXR overall unchanged.
   - Attempting to see if possible to concentrate medications to lessen
   IVF load.
   ARF: Resolved. Creatinine 1.1, from 1.3 yesterday, highest had been 1.4
   in setting of diuresis .
   - Will continue to follow trend.
   Heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan: Consider ultrasound to further
   characterize as outpatient.
   - TSH 0.51 on [**11-1**]
   DM2: FSBG have been running high since transfer up to 300-400. Suspect
   secondary to increased steroid dose, also possibly related to
   infection. FSBG was slightly low yesterday and this AM, so [**Month/Year (2) 3973**] was
   reduced to home dose of 20 units. Elevated insulin needs earlier in
   week may have been due to stress of transfer, possibly infection, but
   with increased steroid dose, this does not seen to be a problem
   currently.
   - [**Name2 (NI) **] and humalog sliding scale.
   FEN: Cardiac, diabetic diet. Will replete electrolytes as needed.
   Communication: Wife, [**Name (NI) 2856**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5547**], and son [**Name (NI) 2667**] [**Name (NI) **]
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5548**]

   hospital-acquired pneumonia and PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) 5604**] pulse dose steroids
   yesterday to treat possible exacerbation of his interstitial lung
   disease. Will continue to monitor over next 24 hrs, as would expect
   some improvement in oxygen need if steroids are helping. No evidence of

   started methylprednisolone 250 mg IV TID for three days.
   - Bactrim IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]), today is day 4, was changed to PO
   yesterday to limit fluid loads.
   - Continue vancomycin and zosyn today for hospital acquired PNA (day 1
   = [**11-3**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed
   - Continue attempt to wean O2, to keep sat >92%
   - Transfused 1 unit yesterday for low HCT, followed by lasix.
   - Biospy or bronchoscopy would be helpful to help guide diagnosis and
   management, however patient
s respiratory status is too tenuous

   concern is that patient would not be able to be extubated.
   Anemia: Improved this AM after yesterday
s transfusion. Etiology still

   bactrim related marrow [**Last Name (LF) 5587**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be cancer related.
   - Monitoring stook guaiac,
   - Hemolysis labs have not been consistent with hemolysis

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a complex medical history, including diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and is currently on 100% high-flow oxygen therapy.

The patient has been treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia and Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP) with levofloxacin, Bactrim, and vancomycin, but his oxygen requirements have not improved. He has also been receiving steroids for possible exacerbation of his interstitial lung disease.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, leukocytosis, and hypocalcemia, which are being monitored. His creatinine levels have decreased from 1.4 to 1.1, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels are within normal range.

The patient's respiratory status is tenuous, and bronchoscopy is not being considered due to the risk of intubation and potential inability to extubate. The patient's family has been informed of his condition, and the patient has expressed a desire to be "DNI" (do not intubate) at this time.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is tenuous, and he may require intubation and mechanical ventilation if his oxygen requirements do not improve.
2. Infection: The patient has been treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia and PCP, but he may still be at risk for developing other infections, such as urinary tract infections or gastrointestinal infections.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if he continues to experience bleeding or if his bone marrow is not producing enough red blood cells.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be a sign of infection or inflammation, and it may require further evaluation and treatment.
5. Hypocalcemia: The patient's hypocalcemia may be a sign of malnutrition or vitamin D deficiency, and it may require supplementation.
6. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient's blood glucose levels have been running high, and he may be at risk for developing diabetic ketoacidosis if his diabetes is not well-controlled.
7. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac history includes coronary artery disease and diastolic congestive heart failure, and he may be at risk for developing cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac failure.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

The patient is a 64-inch tall individual admitted to the ICU with worsening respiratory status, evidenced by chest x-ray showing possible consolidation and oxygen saturations in the 70s. The patient declined morphine and other agents to manage dyspnea. The patient received various antibiotics, including Bactrim, Piperacillin, and Vancomycin, as well as other medications such as Heparin, Insulin, and Metoprolol. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98C, heart rate of 75 bpm, and blood pressure of 123/54 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support includes nasal cannula and high-flow nebulization.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's worsening respiratory status and low oxygen saturation levels increase the risk of respiratory failure.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's chest x-ray shows possible consolidation, which may indicate pneumonia.
3. Legionella infection: Although the urinary antigen test was negative, Legionella infection remains a possibility.
4. Aspiration: The patient's worsening respiratory status and possible consolidation on chest x-ray increase the risk of aspiration.
5. Sepsis: The patient's antibiotic use and worsening respiratory status increase the risk of sepsis.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac diet and medication use, including Metoprolol, may increase the risk of cardiac complications.
7. Hypoglycemia: The patient's insulin use and diabetes diagnosis increase the risk of hypoglycemia.
8. Thrombosis: The patient's use of Heparin and history of DVT prophylaxis increase the risk of thrombosis.
9. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's use of PPI and history of cardiac diet may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications.
10. Infection: The patient's antibiotic use and hospitalization increase the risk of infection.

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of diabetes, interstitial lung disease, diastolic heart failure, coronary artery disease, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and is currently being treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) and possible Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP). His respiratory status has worsened, with oxygen saturations in the 70s, and he is being treated with high-flow oxygen and nebulizer therapy. He is also receiving antibiotics for HAP and PCP, and steroids for possible PCP.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status has worsened, and he is at risk of developing respiratory failure.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has a diagnosis of HAP and possible PCP, and is at risk of developing further complications such as sepsis or respiratory failure.
3. Diastolic heart failure: The patient has a history of diastolic heart failure, and his respiratory status may be exacerbating his cardiac condition.
4. Cholangiocarcinoma: The patient has unresectable cholangiocarcinoma, and his respiratory status may be affecting his ability to tolerate further treatment.
5. Anemia: The patient has anemia, and further evaluation is needed to determine the etiology.
6. Hypotension: The patient has had episodes of hypotension in the past, and his current respiratory status may be exacerbating this condition.
7. Fluid overload: The patient is at risk of developing fluid overload due to his respiratory status and treatment with antibiotics and steroids.
8. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient is at risk of developing electrolyte imbalances due to his respiratory status and treatment with diuretics and antibiotics.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's respiratory status has worsened, and further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause. The patient's anemia and hypotension require further evaluation and treatment. The patient's cholangiocarcinoma requires further evaluation and treatment, and the patient's respiratory status may affect his ability to tolerate further treatment. The patient's fluid overload and electrolyte imbalance require close monitoring and treatment.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic heart failure, and coronary artery disease. He was admitted to the ICU with hypoxia and has been experiencing worsening hypoxia despite treatment. The patient's oxygen saturation is currently 90% on nasal cannula, and he is receiving empiric treatment for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP). He is also receiving treatment for hospital-acquired pneumonia with vancomycin and Zosyn. The patient's anemia is stable, and he is being monitored for potential causes such as hemolysis or cancer-related anemia. His hypotension has resolved, and he is being closely monitored for any signs of recurrence.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's worsening hypoxia and persistent consolidation on chest x-ray suggest that pneumonia is a possible complication.
2. Aspiration: The patient's history of aspiration and recent worsening consolidation on chest x-ray suggest that aspiration is a potential complication.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's worsening hypoxia and need for high-flow oxygen therapy suggest that respiratory failure is a potential complication.
4. Infection: The patient's recent antibiotic treatment and worsening consolidation on chest x-ray suggest that infection is a potential complication.
5. Hemolysis: The patient's anemia and recent treatment with Bactrim suggest that hemolysis is a potential complication.
6. Cancer progression: The patient's diagnosis of unresectable cholangiocarcinoma and recent treatment with chemotherapy suggest that cancer progression is a potential complication.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of coronary artery disease and recent NSTEMI suggest that cardiovascular complications such as heart failure or arrhythmias are potential complications.
8. Thrombotic complications: The patient's recent treatment with heparin and warfarin suggest that thrombotic complications such as deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism are potential complications.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's worsening hypoxia and persistent consolidation on chest x-ray suggest that pneumonia is a possible complication. The patient's anemia is stable, and he is being monitored for potential causes such as hemolysis or cancer-related anemia. The patient's hypotension has resolved, and he is being closely monitored for any signs of recurrence. The patient's treatment plan includes empiric treatment for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP), treatment for hospital-acquired pneumonia with vancomycin and Zosyn, and monitoring for potential complications.

His respiratory status has worsened, with dyspnea worsening when lying down and SaO2 in the mid-80s on NC and NRB. His CXR shows worsening consolidation or aspiration. He has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and diuretics. His laboratory results show anemia, elevated creatinine, and hyperglycemia. He is critically ill and has a DNR/DNI code status.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is worsening, and he is at risk for further deterioration. He may require more aggressive respiratory support, such as mechanical ventilation.
2. Cardiovascular instability: The patient has a history of CHF and CAD, and his creatinine level is elevated. He may be at risk for further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
3. Infection: The patient's respiratory failure may be secondary to an infection, and he is at risk for developing further infections, such as pneumonia or sepsis.
4. Bleeding: The patient's anemia and elevated creatinine level may indicate bleeding, and he may be at risk for further bleeding complications.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may be managed with insulin, but he may be at risk for hypoglycemia if his insulin dose is not adjusted properly.
6. Cholangiocarcinoma progression: The patient's unresectable cholangiocarcinoma may be progressing, and he may require further treatment or palliative care.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his respiratory support as needed.
2. Consider further cardiac evaluation and management, such as echocardiography or cardiology consultation.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's laboratory results and adjust his antibiotic and anticoagulant therapy as needed.
4. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's anemia, such as transfusions or iron supplementation.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's glucose levels and adjust his insulin dose as needed.
6. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's cholangiocarcinoma, such as palliative care or further treatment options.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a complex medical history, including interstitial lung disease (ILD), diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF), recent non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), unresectable cholangiocarcinoma, and hypoxemic respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is stable, with improved dyspnea, but worsening dyspnea when lying down. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula, with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 0.6 and a partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2) of 27 mmHg. The patient's SaO2 is 95% on nasal cannula.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count (WBC) of 13.4, hemoglobin (Hb) of 8.4 g/dL, platelet count (PLT) of 375 K/uL, and creatinine (Cr) of 1.1 mg/dL. The patient's troponin-T level is 0.02, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is 28 mg/dL.

The patient's respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation, with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute. The patient is also receiving continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) at 5 cmH2O.

The patient's cardiovascular system is stable, with a heart rate of 61 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 113/60 mmHg. The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a sinus rhythm.

The patient's neurologic examination is normal, with no evidence of focal deficits or altered mental status.

Based on the patient's condition, potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to respiratory arrest or cardiac arrest.
2. Cardiac failure: The patient's diastolic CHF may worsen, leading to cardiac arrest or heart failure.
3. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and respiratory failure make him susceptible to infection, particularly pneumonia.
4. Bleeding: The patient's anemia and platelet count may increase the risk of bleeding, particularly in the setting of respiratory failure.
5. Liver failure: The patient's cholangiocarcinoma may lead to liver failure, which can worsen his respiratory and cardiovascular status.
6. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and his BUN is slightly elevated, which may indicate early signs of renal failure.
7. Sepsis: The patient's immunocompromised state and respiratory failure make him susceptible to sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ failure.

Based on the patient's condition, the following interventions are recommended:

1. Continue oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation to support the patient's respiratory status.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status closely, and adjust his diuretic therapy as needed.
3. Continue antibiotic therapy for empiric PCP prophylaxis.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function closely, and adjust his diuretic therapy as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function, and adjust his therapy as needed.
6. Consider adding stress ulcer prophylaxis to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Consider adding anticoagulation therapy to prevent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a complex medical history, including ILD, diastolic CHF, recent NSTEMI, unresectable cholangiocarcinoma, and hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient's dyspnea has improved, but he is now reporting worsening dyspnea when lying down. His SaO2 is in the mid-80s on NC and NRB, and his CXR shows worsening consolidation/aspiration.

The patient has received multiple antibiotics, including Bactrim, Piperacillin, Vancomycin, and Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn), and is currently receiving Zosyn IV q8. He is also receiving other medications, including ASA, MVI, Pantoprazole, Zocor, Metoprolol, and Plavix.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a Tmax of 36.9C, HR of 61 bpm, BP of 113/60 mmHg, and SpO2 of 95%. His respiratory support includes oxygen delivery through a nasal cannula at a FiO2 of 0.6L NC.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a Hct of 25.1% and a platelet count of 375 K/uL. His creatinine is elevated at 1.1 mg/dL, and his glucose is 128 mg/dL. His other laboratory results are within normal limits.

The patient's assessment and plan include respiratory failure, CHF/CAD, elevated creatinine, anemia, DM, and cholangiocarcinoma. The plan includes trying to run a net negative balance of 500 cc, starting inh NAC, continuing solumedrol through today and then changing to po prednisone, and continuing Zosyn and Vanc through day 7-26. The patient is also to receive aspirin, statin, and Plavix, and to have gentle diuresis for today.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's worsening consolidation/aspiration on CXR and his requirement for oxygen therapy suggest that he may be at risk for further respiratory deterioration.
2. CHF/CAD: The patient's CHF and CAD may worsen, leading to further cardiac compromise.
3. Elevated creatinine: The patient's elevated creatinine may indicate kidney damage or failure, which could worsen his overall condition.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased oxygen delivery to his tissues.
5. DM: The patient's DM may worsen, leading to further hyperglycemia and potentially life-threatening complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis.
6. Cholangiocarcinoma: The patient's unresectable cholangiocarcinoma may progress, leading to further liver damage and potentially life-threatening complications such as liver failure.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and to improve his overall condition.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a complex medical history, including interstitial lung disease, diastolic CHF, CAD, and recently diagnosed unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and has been experiencing worsening hypoxia.

The patient's recent episode of acute decompensation, characterized by a drop in oxygen saturation to 50-60%, is concerning and may be related to acute hypoxemia. The EKG showed ST depression in the infero-lateral leads, and enzymes were sent to rule out myocardial infarction. The patient has a history of CAD and NSTEMI, and the possibility of acute coronary syndrome cannot be ruled out.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated d-dimer level, which may indicate a hypercoagulable state. He is currently receiving prophylactic heparin, and consideration is being given to initiating heparin therapy if the d-dimer level remains elevated.

The patient's anemia is stable, and the etiology remains unclear. He is receiving transfusions for anemia and hypoxia.

The patient's blood pressure has been fluctuating, and he has experienced hypotension in the past, particularly in the setting of diuresis. His cortisol level is being monitored, and he is receiving steroids for his pulmonary fibrosis.

The patient's cholangiocarcinoma is unresectable, and he is undergoing palliative management. He has a biliary stricture and is at risk for biliary sepsis.

The patient's cardiac status is complex, with a history of NSTEMI and CAD. He is receiving medical management, including aspirin, beta-blockers, and statins, and his cardiac enzymes are being monitored.

The patient's respiratory status is also complex, with a history of interstitial lung disease and pulmonary fibrosis. He is receiving oxygen therapy and nebulizer treatments as needed.

Based on this information, potential medical complications that could arise include:

1. Acute coronary syndrome: The patient's recent episode of acute decompensation and the ST depression on his EKG make it possible that he may be experiencing an acute coronary syndrome.
2. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's elevated d-dimer level and history of pulmonary fibrosis make it possible that he may be at risk for pulmonary embolism.
3. Biliary sepsis: The patient's unresectable cholangiocarcinoma and biliary stricture make it possible that he may be at risk for biliary sepsis.
4. Cardiac failure: The patient's history of diastolic CHF and NSTEMI make it possible that he may be at risk for cardiac failure.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is stable, but it may worsen if his bleeding continues or if he develops a new bleeding source.
6. Hypotension: The patient's history of hypotension and his current blood pressure fluctuations make it possible that he may experience hypotension again.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of interstitial lung disease and pulmonary fibrosis make it possible that he may experience respiratory failure if his oxygen requirements continue to increase.

It is essential to continue to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust his treatment plan as needed to prevent these potential complications from arising.

7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of anemia and may be at risk for gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding or obstruction.
8. Infection: The patient has a history of hospital-acquired PNA, which may increase the risk of infection.

Overall, the patient's condition remains unstable, and close monitoring and treatment are necessary to prevent potential complications.
